Articles.Content:
now check this out!

I'm afraid it's a photoshopped version of this photo of a Philae model in a museum in France.

Food for conspiracy theorists.

People have fun trolling

The Philea mission is very Kerbal Space Program. The descent mechanism was literally just point it at the landing site and hope for the best, very kerbal. Then there was the solution to landing, screws, retrothrusters etc. but they just couldn't say no to harpoons - Jeb would be proud. Then the landing, the landing (and most Kerbal landings) can be summed up as: Systems Nominal...ish. This needs to be a scenario in KSP ASAP. The custom asteroid mod can do the shape of 67P right?

I'm afraid it's a photoshopped version of this photo of a Philae model in a museum in France.

Ooops.. now that's embarassing... lol
Apparently Philae bounced on impact-the harpoons didn't deploy. Good new is that it's still on the comet.

Apparently Philae bounced on impact-the harpoons didn't deploy. Good new is that it's still on the comet.

yes, that would explain the fluctuations in the radio signals and in the amount of light received by the solar panels.

Apparently Philae bounced on impact-the harpoons didn't deploy.

Yep, more and more KSP-like.

A bit like landing on...what was it? The brown, extremely low gravity moon. You tend to bounce off.

The Philea mission is very Kerbal Space Program. The descent mechanism was literally just point it at the landing site and hope for the best, very kerbal. Then there was the solution to landing, screws, retrothrusters etc. but they just couldn't say no to harpoons - Jeb would be proud. Then the landing, the landing (and most Kerbal landings) can be summed up as: Systems Nominal...ish. This needs to be a scenario in KSP ASAP. The custom asteroid mod can do the shape of 67P right?

Support here))

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/99949-can-Squad-add-comets-to-KSP

They basicly think, that Philae bounced off the surface and because the gyros were turned off, the lander started spining, causing fluctuations in the signal. Then it landed again and the fluctuations stopped.
Well, we missed our only chance to harpoon a comet in the near future but at least it landed safely.
Not necessarily. The team is looking into options to manually command the harpoons to fire. May or may not happen, but for now it'll be a while until Rosetta is above the horizon again.

The DSN is currently down sampling data.

https://eyes.nasa.gov/dsn/dsn.htmlc
Wonder how long before Philae is blasted by a geyser.
I got my teacher to watch this in science class today. The suspense was killing me! I am really glad it landed safely and I can't wait to see more pictures!
I'm a bit late to the party... but what an achievement for ESA! Just amazing, even if the harpoons might not have functioned properly. Proud European here .

Not necessarily. The team is looking into options to manually command the harpoons to fire. May or may not happen, but for now it'll be a while until Rosetta is above the horizon again.

Sounds like they for got to set up their Action Groups when they were in the VAB, and are having trouble right clicking on them because of the poor lighting and dark colors. I think if they just install the Action Groups Extended mod, they can set up the action group while they are in flight. Anyone have an email for ESA so I can tell them the fix?

Sounds like they for got to set up their Action Groups when they were in the VAB, and are having trouble right clicking on them because of the poor lighting and dark colors. I think if they just install the Action Groups Extended mod, they can set up the action group while they are in flight. Anyone have an email for ESA so I can tell them the fix?

HQ address:

ESA HQ Mario-Nikis

8-10 rue Mario Nikis

75738 Paris Cedex 15

Sounds like they for got to set up their Action Groups when they were in the VAB, and are having trouble right clicking on them because of the poor lighting and dark colors. I think if they just install the Action Groups Extended mod, they can set up the action group while they are in flight. Anyone have an email for ESA so I can tell them the fix?

No biggie then. F9, fix it, and land again?

No biggie then. F9, fix it, and land again?

Aaaand back on launchpad.

No biggie then. F9, fix it, and land again?

They are actually wondering if it "bounced" on landing. Very Kerbal...

I now want "harpoons" for KSP.

The harpoons did not fire, however the screws are in and there is no concern about its anchoring. The solar panels are producing electricity. Also, the thruster has a priming/perforation process that a sensor did not provide a positive affirmation that it worked, however the ESA confirmed that the thruster works and the sensor is most likely faulty (like getting a check engine light on your car when the only thing wrong is the indicator light itself).

Ah, the news reporting I heard was totally off then. They got the "harpoon and thruster not firing" and were unsure if it has anchored.

Edited November 12, 2014 by Technical Ben

Bruce McCurdy, on a congratulations note from NASA:

Now that those crazy Europeans have pulled it off, let's remind everyone we have three instrument on board!

This thread begs for some more KSP, so here's the Rosetta and Philae I made good few months ago, not really accurate, but does the job:

Post the images/links if you got your own Philae and/or Rosetta I seen some good attempts made while ago, much better than my.

Edited November 12, 2014 by Sky_walker
It almost sounds like they conveniently wanted to omit that message in case of a disaster, har.

I now want "harpoons" for KSP.

Kerbal Attachment System is your friend. It has a grapler that sticks to everything, and you can eject the winches, in the way a harpoon would be.

So where is the ksp Esa cooperation? Similar to ksp nasa.

I think there is/was a major opportunity lost in ksp viral marketing here. Asteroid redirect vs comet landing. Seems all the major game sub components were available for a quick win.

Just my opinion...

magnetic field analysis revealed 3 landings at 15:33, 17:26 and 17:33 UTC

Even with the comet's gravity being as low as it is, a bounce of two hours length would still require reaching a height of about a kilometre. They're extremely lucky Philae is the right way up.
